Project Description  The Project is designed to establish cost-effective and sustainable 
mitigation  measures  for  riverbank  erosion  and  supporting 
institutions to protect the livelihoods of 2 million people living in the 
two flood protection and irrigation schemes that were developed 
with  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance  and  are 
threatened by the progressive erosion caused by the Jamuna and 
Meghna rivers: Pabna Irrigation and Rural Development Project 
(PIRDP) and Meghna-Dhonagoda Irrigation Project (MDIP). The 
Project will implement innovative approaches for erosion mitigation 
for this purpose: (i) protecting the riverbanks through an adaptive 
approach of placing revetments along the natural river alignments 
as needed; and (ii) using sand-filled geotextile bags, a lower cost 
and  labor-intensive  alternative  to  conventional  materials. 
Institutional  development  support  will  focus  on  the  full 
implementation of the key principles of the 1999 National Water 
Policy  (NWP)  applied  to  the  Project  institutions  including  the 
operation of joint management committees (JMCs) by the national 
Government, local governments, and diverse stakeholders.  
   
Rationale  Riverbank  erosion  is  a  perennial  problem  in  Bangladesh  that 
displaces over 100,000 people annually with devastating social 
and  poverty  impacts  along  the  major  rivers,  where  poverty  is 
heavily concentrated. The dynamic river process in the Jamuna 
and Meghna rivers is currently critically threatening the PIRDP and 
MDIP flood embankments. If unattended, the process is likely to 
erode  the  embankments  in  the  very  near  future,  resulting  in 
inundation of the project area affecting the livelihoods of up to 2 
million people and significantly reversing the momentum of poverty 
reduction, due to the loss of agriculture and other benefits secured 
by the embankments, including local institutions for participatory 
water management. About 1,700 hectares (ha) of highly productive 
agricultural lands and homesteads are also expected to be eroded, 
displacing  28,000  people  as  asset-less  poor  over  the  next  10 
years.   
Despite the urgent need to protect the project area, conventional 
protection structures using hard materials to actively control the 
river channels require high investment and maintenance costs and 
are infeasible. On the other hand, retiring the embankments could 
be less costly, but results in significant social disruption associated

livelihoods  of  many  vulnerable  people  threatened  by  riverbank 
erosion in the floodplains of Bangladesh.        
   
Objectives and Scope  The Project aims to sustain the incomes of people in the PIRDP 
and  MDIP  areas  through  establishing  sustainable  riverbank 
erosion  management  system  (REMS)  that  provide  reliable  and 
cost-effective  mitigation  measures  through  adaptive  riverbank 
protection works and a range of nonstructural instruments to adapt 
to  the  dynamic  morphological  processes  of  the  Jamuna  and 
Meghna  rivers.  The  project  scope  comprises  (i)  about  7.0 
kilometers (km) and 4.4 km of riverbank protection works in PIRDP 
and MDIP, respectively through placement of revetments using 
sand-filled geotextile bags; (ii) nonstructural river erosion mitigation 
measures including data and information management, disaster 
preparedness, and targeted social development to the erosion-
displaced  poor;  and  (iii)  institutional  strengthening  of  REMS 
including capacity development and project management.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Jamuna-Meghna  River  Erosion  Mitigation

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Sector  Description.  Poverty  remains  a  massive  and  predominant  problem  in 
Bangladesh, with 44% of its population of over 130 million living under the poverty line. Given 
that over 80% of the poor live in rural areas engaged in agriculture and related nonfarm 
activities, enhancing agricultural and rural development is a key to reducing poverty in the 
country. Due to the geographical location of Bangladesh in the confluence of three major 
rivers― Jamuna, Ganges, and Meghna―the livelihood of the poor is fundamentally affected by 
water sector challenges generated by this major river system, including (i) massive floods in the 
monsoon season, (ii) severe water scarcity in the dry season, (iii) riverbank erosion and siltation 
of watercourses, (iv) periodic natural disasters such as cyclones and tidal surges, and (v) 
widespread arsenic contamination of groundwater. While sustainable water management is 
paramount for the prosperity of the poor and overall economic growth, the task is further 
complicated  by  diverse  social  interests  attached  to  different  livelihood  activities  and  the 
vulnerable  natural  environment,  which  are  affected  by  water  management  activities.  The 
country’s sector policies and institutional framework and capacities remain weak to meet these 
diverse challenges comprehensively, and in a participatory and strategic manner.  
3.  Riverbank  Erosion.  Riverbank  erosion  is  a  perennial  problem  caused  by  dynamic 
channel shifting of the rivers flowing through the unconsolidated sediments of the floodplain. 
Nationwide, an estimated 1,200 kilometers (km) of riverbank in the major rivers is actively 
eroding, with more than 500 km having severe erosion problems. An estimated 10,000 hectares 
(ha) of floodplain land is lost annually, with the emergence of new but much smaller and short-
lived low-lying char lands, which exhibit a significantly reduced production base. This process 
annually affects about 100,000 local people, who face significant social hardships such as loss 
of  homestead,  becoming  landless,  and  being  displaced  to  the  riverine  fringe  land,  nearby 
embankments, char lands, or urban slums. In total some 5 million people live in the active 
floodplain of the major rivers susceptible to bank erosion, of whom 2 million live on vulnerable 
char land. Poverty incidence is significantly higher in these areas due to river erosion. Past 
efforts to mitigate the effects of erosion have not produced tangible outputs, due to the lack of 
cost-effective mitigation measures that can effectively cope with the highly dynamic, erratic, and 
unavoidable morphological changes of the major rivers in Bangladesh.2  
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities

the flood embankments in the two subproject sites of the ongoing Loan No. 1399-BAN(SF) 
Command  Area  Development  Project  (CADP),  comprising  the  Pabna  Irrigation  and  Rural

5.  However, natural river erosion has accelerated along the PIRDP and MDIP since the 
late 1990s, reducing the distance between the bank and the flood embankments from about 1 
km to none in some critical reaches. While the Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB) 
implemented immediate interim works in 2001 and 2002, mobilizing its own resources to protect 
the flood embankments, the embankments are likely to fail in the very near future without 
permanent protection works, which would lead to the inundation of the area and substantial loss 
of flood protection and irrigation benefits along with the deterioration of local WMAs, affecting 
the  people  within  the  embankments.  The  momentum  of  poverty  reduction  would  also  be 
reversed, with substantial increase in the number of the poor due to the lost agriculture and 
other  benefits.  The  process  would  also  erode  1,700  ha  of  homestead,  embankment,  and

6.  Government Policies and Plans. In recent years, the Government has proceeded with 
water sector reforms to address past shortcomings. The 1999 National Water Policy (NWP) 
adopted the principles of integrated water management with due emphasis on stakeholder 
participation, strategic planning, sound management of social and environmental issues, and 
sustainable O&M. Following the NWP, comprehensive reforms of sector institutions have been 
initiated to meet the policy principles, including the reorganization of BWDB and improvement of 
the legal and regulatory framework and investment plan. On the legal and regulatory side, the 
Water Act is under preparation to comprehensively govern the utilization and management of 
water. Guidelines for participatory water management have also been finalized that stipulate the 
management transfer and local participation arrangements in water resources schemes. The 
Government also prepared the National Water Management Plan (NWMP) recently, which lays 
out strategies and priority programs at the national and regional levels. The Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) played a key role during the process, with its assistance strategy focusing on 
promoting an improved policy and institutional environment while addressing the significant 
capacity  constraints  to  implement  the  reforms  and  providing  critical  infrastructure.  (See

7.  Opportunities for Riverbank Erosion Mitigation in PIRDP and MDIP. The NWP and 
NWMP have accorded high priority to mitigating the effects of riverbank erosion in view of its 
significant poverty implications. However, effective strategy, measures, and institutions to cope 
with the problem have not been established in Bangladesh. According to a study conducted 
under the CADP in 2000, conventional structures using hard materials and taking an active 
approach to controlling river channels required high capital and O&M costs and resulted in low 
economic returns. On the other hand, the alternative option of a phased retirement of the 
embankments was found less costly, but would result in significant social disruption associated 
with continued loss of land and dislocation of over 28,000 people in the next 10 years, rendering 
this option socially unattractive and opposed. It is also difficult to urgently implement this option 
before the existing embankment is breached, a major factor undermining its economic viability. 
Thus, there was identified an urgent need to develop more cost-effective, socially desirable, and 
sustainable mitigation measures commensurate with the land use in the areas they protect; and 
that were within the fiscal capacity of the local institutions and the Government; and that could 
be sustained under the highly dynamic morphological environment of the major rivers.  
8.  Appropriate Alternative. From this perspective, an alternative approach was identified 
and developed under the project preparatory technical assistance (footnote1) through detailed 
assessments of the morphological process and studies of the lessons learned in Bangladesh 
and in other parts of the world. (See Appendix 5 for project alternatives.) In contrast to the past 
interventions, the proposed measures provided a passive and adaptive approach to managing 
river erosion by placing the protection works parallel to the natural alignment of the river system. 
This would reduce the risks of severe attack resulting in structural failure and high maintenance 
costs. The protection works would consist of a revetment with launching sections, to cover and 
protect the existing bank line as the scour holes develop. They are constructed of sand-filled 
geotextile bags, which can be placed at about half the cost of conventional hard materials and 
have the advantage of using sand and labor, the most abundant resources in Bangladesh. This 
is to be implemented with a range of nonstructural measures including the establishment of and 
development  of  capacity  in  riverbank  management  institutions  that  incorporate  stakeholder 
participation and ownership, and effective O&M systems with local cost recovery. Successful 
implementation  will  serve  as  a  model  for  effective  and  sustainable  mitigation  of  riverbank 
erosion that can be replicated throughout the country, thereby contributing to the livelihood 
protection of poverty-stricken local communities occupying the erosion-prone floodplains.  
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objective 
9.  The goal of the proposed Project is to sustain and enhance economic growth, poverty 
reduction, and livelihood security in areas threatened by riverbank erosion. Its specific objective 
is to sustain the incomes of people in PIRDP and MDIP areas4 through establishing cost-
effective and sustainable riverbank erosion management system (REMS) that provide reliable 
mitigation measures through adaptive riverbank protection works and a range of nonstructural 
instruments to adapt to the highly dynamic morphological processes of the Jamuna and the 
Meghna rivers while protecting and enhancing the livelihoods of the poor in the project areas.

B.  Components and Outputs 
10.  The scope or components of the Project include (i) riverbank protection works, (ii) non-
structural river erosion mitigation measures, and (iii) institutional strengthening of REMS. They 
will be provided focusing on PIRDP and MDIP areas. For the purpose of effective monitoring 
and achievement of outputs, the Project has distinct performance targets towards its midterm 
review (MTR) in the third year and its completion. Implementation after MTR is designed based 
on the performance of the output targets and other policy dialogue agreements, in particular the 
satisfactory implementation of bank protection works and achievement of institutional targets.  
 
1.  Part A: Riverbank Protection Works for the PIRDP and MDIP  
11.  The Project will provide riverbank protection works to stabilize the critical sections of the 
riverbank  along  the  flood  embankments  in  the  PIRDP  and  MDIP,  following  an  “adaptive 
approach” to protect and stabilize the riverbank along smooth alignments that are parallel to the 
river systems without changing the flow pattern, thereby reducing turbulence and the resulting 
scour more effectively than active structures that control and stand against the channel flows 
more directly. An estimated total of 7.0 km and 4.4 km reach of riverbank will be protected in the 
PIRDP and MDIP, respectively.5 The protection works will comprise (i) riverbank revetment with 
launching aprons using sand-filled graded geotextile bags that start to fall down and cover the 
eroding banks as the scour holes develop, (ii) upper bank line revetment with concrete blocks, 
and (iii) grass turfing along a strip of the bank at the crest of the revetment.6 (See Figure A11.3 
for illustrative figure of erosion control mechanism.) 
12.  The placement of protection works will follow a phased and process-type approach. The 
works during years 1 and 2 will consist of a pilot-cum-implementation approach to reconfirm and 
define optimal design criteria and implementation approaches with intensive monitoring and 
evaluation. Specifically, protection works will initially concentrate on the most critical reaches of 
the bank line along the PIRDP and MDIP. Detailed evaluation of the effectiveness of the 
protection measures will be made in preparing the annual implementation plan, which will be 
submitted for ADB approval each year. Further reinforcement and extension of protection works 
will be provided as necessary, in response to the river conditions prevailing at the time, and all 
threatened  sections  will  be  protected  by  the  end  of  the  implementation  period.  Sufficient 
financial provision has been included to cope with the level of the scour depth observed under 
more active structures applied in Bangladesh.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Technical Issues 
48.  The  Project  aims  to  establish  cost  effective,  sustainable  and  innovative  riverbank 
protection measures. However, river morphology in the Jamuna and the Meghna rivers is 
generally highly dynamic, for which accurate prediction is not possible beyond the short term of 
2–3 years. In response to the uncertainty of morphological behavior beyond short terms, an 
“adaptive approach” was developed, which will place protection works as and where needed 
and along the smooth and flat alignments that are natural to the river system, and stabilize the 
channel along those alignments with sufficient design to withstand further scour. Following this 
approach, the Project will protect over 50% of the bank lines along the flood embankments of 
the PIRDP and MDIP.18 Over the long period of years, the entire bank line may have to be 
protected, although a major morphological change has to happen to necessitate the protection 
of the remaining sections,19 and the morphological attack on the bank line protected under the 
Project  would  recede  under  such  circumstance.  In  the  project  design,  the  costs  of  these 
additional works are incorporated in the economic analysis over its 30-year economic life, with a 
sensitivity analysis of adverse morphological scenario where protection works for the remaining 
sections are placed immediately after project completion, in justifying the project investment. 
(See overall technical assessment in Appendix 11.) 
49.  The selected design option under this approach is the revetment with launching aprons 
of sand-filled graded geotextile bags placed in the river at the top of the eroding bank. The large 
amount of bags built up along the bank will slide down the slope when river erosion undercuts it 
and will cover the bank to arrest the erosion. Concrete slabs will be placed on the prepared 
slope above low water level to provide a layer resistant to wave erosion. The bank protection is 
based on the intensive monitoring of river conditions and short-term morphological prediction 
using  satellite  images  and  is  provided  to  cover  the  critical  sections  of  the  riverbank.  All 
processes including survey, design, and construction need to be carried out rapidly after the 
monsoon floods and completed during the subsequent dry season.  
50.   A “launching revetment” using hard materials has been successfully implemented with 
low annual maintenance costs of about 0.4% of investment costs in the Mississippi River, which 
has similar morphological characteristics to the major rivers in Bangladesh. However, the same 
measure using geotextile bags has limited application history.20 While intensive data collection 
and  physical  model  testing  undertaken  during  the  PPTA  and  performance  monitoring  of 
geotextile bags placed during the interim works by the Government in 2001 and 2002 have 
provided positive indications, there remain some technical uncertainties for which verification 
will require intensive field monitoring, such as launching performance in deeper scours. To 
address those risks, the project design has incorporated built-in contingencies amounting to 
over 23% of base cost, comprising physical contingencies (10%), adoption of conservative 
design  scour  depth  (which  amounts  to  over  10%),21  and  reserve  stockpiles  (about  3%). 
Intensive  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  performance  of  the  protection  works  will  be 
undertaken during the first two years with the support of the independent panel of experts,

B.  Economic Benefits 
51.  Economic analysis was carried out for the PIRDP and MDIP to evaluate the returns on 
project investments (Appendix 12), with its economic life of 30 years. The major benefits of the 
Project are also shown in Appendix 1 as output performance targets. The estimated economic 
internal rates of return (EIRRs) are 16.7% for the PIRDP and 31.4% for the MDIP. The EIRR for 
the PIRDP is lower due to the longer bank sections that have to be protected and the deeper 
scour depth seen in the Jamuna River. Sensitivity analysis was undertaken to test the project 
viability covering a range of scenarios including the uncertain and dynamic morphology. In the 
PIRDP, the EIRR in the event of a 20% decrease in incremental future agricultural and fishery 
development will reduce the EIRR to 14.0%. A 20% increase in protection works will reduce the 
EIRR to 12.6%.22 A significant morphological change that necessitates the protection of the 
remaining riverbank sections immediately after the Project will also reduce the EIRR to 13.1%. 
On the other hand, at the MIRDP the EIRR remains significantly above 20% in all of these 
scenarios. These indicate that an investment in the MDIP is fairly robust, whereas in the PIRDP 
it is relatively vulnerable, although it remains viable in all sensitivity analysis cases. However, 
the PIRDP has a higher poverty incidence, with high poverty impact ratio (para. 52).23  
 
C.  Poverty Impacts 
52.  The  Project  will  have  direct  positive  impacts  on  the  income  and  employment 
opportunities  and  the  food  security  situation  of  poor  people.  According  to  the  sample 
socioeconomic survey, poverty incidence among the beneficiary households in the irrigation 
command area and adjacent riverine areas of the PIRDP and MDIP is lower than in the 
neighboring areas by about 10-15%, although it is still 53% and 47%, respectively, which is 
higher than the national average of 44% in 2000. Over the years, there has been a significant 
increase  in  production  and  yield  of  rice  crops  and  a  reduction  in  poverty,  thanks  to  the 
implementation of the CADP. Overall, the poor may attain a total of about 45% and 42% of 
direct and indirect project benefits in the PIRDP and MDIP, respectively, when production and 
labor benefits are taken into account. These benefits will be lost due to erosion under the 
without-project scenario, reversing the trend of poverty reduction (Appendix 13).  
 
53.  The causes of poverty in the project areas are multidimensional. In both areas, the 
distribution of existing resources such as land is extremely skewed. The landless and marginal 
households together account for about 62% and 74% of total households in the PIRDP and 
MDIP, respectively. As these areas are erosion-prone, a large number of households may 
further  lose  their  homesteads,  cultivable  land,  and  other  assets  completely  and  become 
assetless. A vast majority of people displaced by erosion have remained in the area, adding to 
the existing number of poor households.24 Groundwater arsenic is also a major concern, with 
17% and 90% of the tubewells contaminated in the PIRDP and MDIP, respectively.25 Traditional 
social and local power structure induced an increased dependence of the poor while excluding

E.  Environmental Impacts  
55.  An  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA)  was  carried  out  during  the  feasibility 
studies.26 The Project will have overall beneficial impacts, preserving the existing and potential 
benefits of the PIRDP and MDIP schemes as well as protecting the livelihood of the population 
in  the  erosion-prone  areas  nearby.  Potential  negative  impacts  identified  under  summary 
environmental impact assessment (SEIA) include (i) mining, transportation and storage of sand; 
(ii) construction-related impacts including health hazards and accidental injury of workers; (iii) 
land acquisition and resettlement; and (iv) possible erosion of sandbars/chars and changes in 
river morphology. On these accounts, the impact of sand mining will be negligible, given the 
amount of sand required for construction during the 6-year Project of about 1 million metric tons 
compared with the annual bed load transport of the Jamuna and the lower Meghna of more than 
150 and 200 million metric tons. The morphological impacts are also estimated to be limited, as 
the structures do not confront the flow and cause great scouring. The sandbars and the char 
closest to the protected portion are uninhabited and largely without vegetation. The Project will 
closely  monitor  the  morphological  process,  and  if  significant  changes  originate  from  the 
protection works, a compensation program will be implemented.

G.  Risks  
60.  The Project has certain risks that could adversely affect the effective implementation and 
sustainability of its benefits. These risks include (i) technical and morphological risks of the 
selected  design  measures,  (ii)  risks  of  implementation  in  terms  of  delivering  the  required 
services  and  works  appropriately  within  the  limited  construction  period,  and  (iii)  O&M 
sustainability.  The  project  design  has  incorporated  measures  mitigating  those  risks  to  the 
maximum possible extent.   
61.  Regarding the technical risks associated with the limited experience of the revetment 
using  geotextile  bags,  significant  contingencies  have  been  built  in  through  adoption  of 
conservative  design  scour  depth  and  stockpiling  arrangements  (para.  50),  with  economic 
sensitivity  analysis  of  a  further  cost  increase  by  20%  to  justify  the  investment.  Similarly, 
sensitivity analysis of significantly more severe morphological change was carried out to assess 
the viability against the morphological risks. Project implementation also envisages intensive 
M&E with the involvement of an external panel of experts.  
62.  The implementation risk is associated with the critical need to undertake and complete 
bank protection works of any year within one dry season, including during 2002/03 dry season. 
This  requires  expeditious  fielding  of  consultants,  procurement,  and  implementation  of 
resettlement  activities,  and  stringent  quality  control.  The  project  design  has  included  the 
arrangements for engaging consultants for pre-construction services and contract management 
as  “the  engineers  representatives.”  ADB  is  also  to  select  consultants  on  behalf  of  the 
Government. The Government also initiated necessary advance actions to ensure the timely 
initiation of the project activities.     
63.  Finally, there is a sustainability risk associated with (i) local institutional development, 
and (ii) BWDB capacities to rationalize and prioritize O&M budgetary management. To address 
these risks, the Project has incorporated institutional support to strengthen the capacities of 
BWDB engineers, extension officers, CBOs, and other JMC representatives. Regarding the 
O&M funding sustainability, specific arrangements to ensure the sufficient allocation of O&M 
funds to the Project were agreed upon with the Government, including the introduction of a 
performance-based O&M budgetary allocation mechanism to the project entities having eligible 
institutional performance as monitored through specific indicators.

SECTOR ANALYSIS: 
 BANGLADESH WATER RESOURCES SECTOR 
 
 
1.  Rural Poverty. Bangladesh remains one of the poorest countries in the world, with a per 
capita income of approximately $360 in 2000. The most recent countrywide poverty data show 
that 44% of the population was poor, and 20% extremely poor. With a population of over 130 
million, Bangladesh suffers from massive poverty. It is predominantly a rural phenomenon, as 
more than 90 % of the poor live in rural areas. It is multifaceted, reflected in low standards of 
living, poor health and nutrition, and lack of education, abandonment of women and children, 
and vulnerability to natural disasters such as floods and cyclones. The basic causes of poverty 
are lack of access to productive resources (mainly land and water); public resources such as 
education, health provision, and transport; and jobs. Lack of social and government safety nets 
entitlements  makes  the  land-poor  and  landless  particularly  vulnerable.  Poverty  is  largely 
attributed to weak rural and agricultural development.  
 
2.  Water  Resources  and  Their  Implications.  Bangladesh  is  in  an  alluvial  deltaic 
floodplain  in  the  confluence  of  the  three  major  rivers–the  Ganges  (Padma),  Jamuna 
(Brahmaputra), and Meghna, which have a catchment area of 1.74 million square kilometers 
(km2) and bring about massive annual floods that inundate up to two thirds of the country. For 
rural people, access to productive resources, particularly to land and water, is of fundamental 
importance to their livelihoods, although the people’s relations with water are diverse and 
complex. Integrated and sustainable water resource management is required to meet people’s 
diverse  needs  while  preserving  the  rich  natural  ecosystems  in  the  country’s  extraordinary 
environment characterized by (i) severe flooding, which not only inundates large areas but also 
fills river channels with sediment and erodes riverbanks; (ii) limited water during the dry season 
and expanding water demand; (iii) saline intrusion and environmental degradation; (iv) cyclones 
and tidal surges that decimate life and property in the coastal areas; and (v) widespread arsenic 
contamination of groundwater.  
 
3.  Agriculture is the centerpiece of the economy and supports the vast majority of the  
population, accounting for 32% of gross domestic product (GDP), 13% of exports, and 60% of 
employment. The sector has exhibited strong growth since the late 1980s, contributing to lower 
food grain prices and benefiting poor households. However, sustaining agricultural growth to 
keep pace with the expanding population presents a fundamental challenge where increased 
irrigation and flood management is a critical requirement. The country also needs to preserve 
resources for capture fishery and expand culture fishery with effective flood management and 
improved access rights of the poor to publicly owned water bodies. The natural environment has 
been under increasing pressure, with declining soil fertility, land degradation, biodiversity loss, 
and deteriorating water quality due to urbanization and intensification of agriculture and fish 
culture with increased use of chemical inputs. The establishment of effective and sustainable 
water management systems is an important part of protecting natural resources.  
 
4.  Sector Institutions. The National Water Resources Council (NWRC), chaired by the 
Prime  Minister,  is  the  highest  authority  governing  the  water  resources  sector.  The  Water 
Resources Planning Organization (WARPO) has been established under the Ministry of Water 
Resources as the secretariat to the NWRC. Some 35 government organizations affiliated with 
13 ministries have some involvement in water resource management. The key implementing 
agency among these are the Bangladesh Water Development Board (BWDB), responsible for 
water resource projects exceeding 1,000 hectares (ha); and the Local Government Engineering 
Department, responsible for projects below 1,000 ha. In general, despite the dire need for sound

framework and capacities have been unable to meet these diverse challenges comprehensively 
and in a participatory and strategic manner. Key institutional issues include (i) weakness in 
participatory, integrated, and strategic planning; (ii) agency’s lack of capacity to implement water 
resource interventions to achieve the intended benefits; (iii) inability of local institutions to 
support the participatory process; (iv) deficient operation and maintenance (O&M) of many 
public schemes due to insufficient mobilization of funds by central and local governments and 
the lack of support from beneficiaries; and (v) corruption. 
 
5.  Past Interventions and Lessons Learned. External funding agencies have provided 
assistance exceeding $2.5 billion to the Bangladesh water resources sector. Of this, the Asian 
Development Bank provided $600 million, and the World Bank $1.0 billion. Bilateral assistance 
has been provided by 15 countries, of which the Netherlands provided the most at more than 
$200 million. Funding assistance was relatively low in late 1990s. ADB has provided 17 loans of 
almost $600 million to water management initiatives. All investments resulted in increased 
agricultural production although increases were less than anticipated at appraisal. The extent to 
which  ongoing  system  maintenance  was  undertaken  governed  the  sustainability  of  these 
production increases. Environmental impacts of the investments were evaluated as generally 
either benign or positive, but the early projects that substantially altered floodplain regimes had 
negative impacts on open-water capture fisheries, including the Pabna Irrigation and Rural 
Development Project (PIRDP) and Meghna-Dhonagoda Irrigation Project (MDIP). Key lessons 
over the past two decades can be grouped into 6 themes:  
 
(i)  Beneficiary  participation.  Sufficient  time,  resources,  and  a  clear  and  well-defined 
process to establish local organizations and their legal status are essential, along with 
effective management of the participatory process. Linkages to other sectors must be 
recognized and reflected in implementation. 
(ii)  Environment. Environmental planning must be undertaken early in the project cycle to 
avoid  and  minimize  adverse  environmental  impacts.  Monitoring  of  environmental 
impacts and implementation of mitigation plan must also be improved.   
(iii)  Planning. Rehabilitation of existing systems provides potentially large returns, given the 
system’s quick gestation period and small social and environmental impacts. Planning 
should also be participatory and fully take into account cross-sectoral perspectives to 
maximize the benefits of potential interventions.  
(iv)  Implementation. Construction supervision and quality control require rigorous attention, 
as  poor  construction  quality  affects  maintenance  requirements  and  discourages 
beneficiary  involvement  in  O&M.  Effective  oversight  mechanism  of  the  construction 
process should be established.  
(v)  O&M. O&M activities need to be planned early in the project cycle and must involve and 
train beneficiaries. Project designs must recognize agency capacity to support O&M, and 
beneficiary contributions need to be collected before any commitment to proceed with 
construction. Finally, farmers are more likely to contribute to O&M if the level of service 
is high. 
(vi)  Management. The commitment of executing agencies to the poverty agenda must be 
strengthened. Management information systems are important and project designs need 
to clearly spell out arrangements for coordinated support from government agencies. 
Disaster  rehabilitation  projects  require  rapid  preparation  and  simple  disbursement 
arrangements to provide timely relief to affected populations.

6.  Recent Policy and Institutional Reforms. In recent years, the Government has been 
making steady progress in establishing a comprehensive policy, planning, institutional, and legal 
framework for the water sector. The National Water Policy (NWP) was approved in 1999, 
adopting  the  principles  of  integrated  water  resources  management  with  due  emphasis  on 
stakeholder participation, strategic planning, decentralization, sound management of social and 
environmental issues, sustainable O&M through management transfer to water management 
associations  (WMAs),  and  transparency  and  accountability  of  sector  institutions.  BWDB 
institutional  reforms  have  also  been  initiated,  which  include  (i)  structuring  of  the  Board  of 
directors  to  include  stakeholder  representatives  to  decide  on  policy  issues;  (ii)  long-term 
assignment of leadership; (iii) staff reduction; and (iv) diversification of skill mix. The reform also 
envisages transforming regional entities into autonomous boards with a similar participatory 
setup.  On  the  legal  and  regulatory  side,  the  national  water  act  is  under  preparation  to 
comprehensively govern the utilization and management of water. Guidelines for participatory 
water management (GPWM) have also been finalized, stipulating the management transfer and 
local participation arrangements in water resources schemes. The Government also recently 
prepared the national water management plan (NWMP), which lays out national and regional 
strategies and priority programs for the next 25 years. 
 
7.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  played  a  key  role  in  promoting  these  sector 
reforms.  Specifically,  ADB’s  assistance  to  the  small-scale  water  resources  subsector1 
encouraged the Government to decentralize the management of small-scale schemes to local 
government institutions and WMAs, which was adopted in the NWP. The procedures and 
arrangements  developed  under  the  project  were  also  used  as  a  model  for  GPWM.  The 
assistance in the Command Area Development Project2 is also establishing and putting into 
operation the participatory water management framework for large flood control, drainage, and 
irrigation (FCDI) schemes as a leading model to apply the key NWP principles, including full 
cost recovery of irrigation O&M by WMAs, and a transparent and accountable joint management 
framework of the Government and stakeholders. ADB has also been providing regular advice 
for the preparation of NWMP and national water act.   
 
8.  ADB’s  Sectoral  Operational  Strategy:  Consistent  with  the  Poverty  Reduction 
Partnership Agreement (PRPA) signed between ADB and and the Government in April 2000, 
ADB’s  operational  strategy  for  Bangladesh  identified  poverty  reduction  as  its  overarching 
objective. Given the high incidence of rural poverty, agriculture and rural sectors have been 
accorded  high  priority,  with  operational  focus  on  the  crop/agribusiness  credit,  rural 
infrastructure, water resources development, and microfinance. In the water resources sector, 
ADB’s strategy is to support the achievement of goals, objectives, and strategies articulated in 
NWP and NWMP within the framework of the PRPA and country operational strategy which 
emphasizes  (i)  integrated  and  sustainable  water  resource  management  by  enhancing 
stakeholder participation and empowerment, (ii) improving financial efficiency and sustainability, 
and  (iii)  helping  the  poor  rural  population  while  not  disturbing  the  natural  environment. 
Developing policies, institutional framework, and capacities of central and local governments 
and community organizations to apply these principles is accorded high priority, based on which 
assistance to build critical infrastructure will be provided.

PROJECT ALTERNATIVES 
 
 
1.  Background.  The  River  Erosion  Prevention  and  Morphology  Study,  prepared  in 
November 2000, comprised a prefeasibility study for several bank protection and mitigation 
measures. Under the current study, a further options assessment was undertaken. Conventional 
structures such as revetments with deep setting level with hard and/or interconnected materials 
and high spurs were found to be far more expensive than other options and had low economic 
return and high maintenance costs. While low permeable spurs were identified as a potential 
alternative, the piling alone showed to cost three times more than the low solid spurs and was 
consequently dropped. The following options were taken forward for the feasibility study: 
(i)  without project,  
(ii)  embankment retirement (inward shifting of embankment), 
(iii)  riverbank protection by revetment, 
(iv)  riverbank protection by low solid spur. 
 
2.  Without  Project.  In  the  without-project  scenario,  river  erosion  will  continue.  The 
estimated loss of land by river erosion over the last 10 years is 1,358 hectares (ha) in Pabna 
Irrigation and Rural Development Project (PIRDP) and 416 ha in Meghna-Dhonagoda Irrigation 
Project (MDIP). With the expected average erosion rate over the next 30 years, it is estimated 
that 3,002 ha will be eroded in PIRDP and 2,242 ha in MDIP. Some of the erosion at the project 
sites  is  expected  to  cause  sediment  deposition  and  generation  of  new  land  elsewhere. 
However, newly accreted land is of low value and generally takes up to 20 years before it 
becomes productive. 
3.  In a without-project scenario, the embankment will be breached to inundate the project 
area, damaging the terrestrial and aquatic environment. Annual floods will reduce agricultural 
production  by  approximately  11%  in  PIRDP  and  39%  in  MDIP.  Flooding  will  also  have  a 
negative impact on water supply, sanitation, and health. The floodplains will revert to supporting 
aquatic life during the flood season, which will have a significant impact on fisheries and culture 
fish production. A considerable part of the production capacity of the pond culture will be lost, 
while the capture fishery can be reinstated. However, on the whole, the increase in fisheries 
production in PIRDP will be minimal.  
4.  Embankment Retirement. Under an embankment retirement scenario (as well as the 
without-project  scenario)  continued  river  erosion  will  accelerate  the  cycle  of  environmental 
degradation in the project area, where people displaced by erosion move to remaining marginal 
land, causing further deterioration of natural resources and reduction of terrestrial biodiversity in 
MDIP and PIRDP. 
5.  In PIRDP, over the past 15 years at least 2,500 households have lost their homestead 
lands to river erosion and been forced to move, some to the embankment. In the next 30 years, 
around 7,000 households could be lost in PIRDP as a result of erosion including the 2,425 living 
outside the embankment and others just on and behind it. In MDIP, over the past 15 years, 
about 4,000 households are estimated to have lost their homesteads, of which about 600 are 
squatting on and along the embankment. Another 2,900 households or so have migrated to the 
project area, and about 500 to the opposite side of the rivers. In the next 30 years, 5,450 
households could be lost due to bank retreat as a result of erosion.

6.  Riverbank Protection and Comparative Assessment. Riverbank protection through 
revetment and low spurs intends to stabilize the riverbank following an “adaptive approach” to 
protect  and  stabilize  the  riverbank  along  smooth  alignments  that  are  parallel  to  the  river 
systems. By using sand-filled graded geotextile bags, it can be implemented at about half the 
cost  of  conventional  hard  materials.  This  option  was  compared  to  the  without-project  and 
embankment retirement scenarios using a multicriterion analysis including economic, social, 
and  environmental  consequences.  (See  a  summary  of  alternatives  analysis  in  Table  A5.)               
The overall analysis shows that embankment retirement is cheaper than riverbank protection. 
However,  embankment  retirement  entails  significant  social  disruption  and  environmental 
impacts associated with continued loss of agriculture and homestead land and dislocation of 
28,000 people in the next 10 years, which make this choice socially unattractive. The financial 
cost of embankment retirement for the two subprojects in the 30-year project life is estimated at 
$44.1 million against the revetment option of $78.9 million. However, the cost of embankment 
retirement does not include the lost income opportunities of those who lose their land due to 
river erosion, estimated at $52.7 million valued at the present market price. 
7.  Embankment retirement is also not practical as mitigation measures are urgently needed 
in  the  project  area  to  cope  with  river  erosion,  and  in  view  of  (i)  strong  opposition  by 
stakeholders; (ii) lack of social safety nets accepted by the stakeholders (who request full 
compensation of lost assets) and the Government (which does not compensate loss of assets 
due  to  the  natural  phenomenon  of  river  erosion);  and  (iii)  time-consuming  procedural 
requirements for land acquisition and resettlement, and provision of necessary social safety 
nets. Embankment retirement is also generally used as a rehabilitation rather than protective 
measure  against  flood  damage.1  If  the  retired  embankment  is  not  constructed  before  the 
existing embankment is undercut by erosion in PIRDP and MDIP, the economic viability of the 
embankment retirement will be significantly undermined due to substantial inundation damage, 
deterioration  of  cropping  patterns  due  to  loss  of  confidence  among  farmers,  and  added 
rehabilitation costs.  
8.  Public Consultation. Having thoroughly evaluated the alternative from a multicriterion 
perspective, the Government and ADB consulted the major stakeholders, representatives of the 
concerned central and local governments and nongovernment organizations, and national and 
international experts. A consensus emerged that embankment retirement should be avoided 
due to its highly adverse social impacts as long as an economically feasible alternative exists.  
9.  Selected Design Option. While the two riverbank-protection options have similar costs 
and economic returns, the low-spur option is viable where the riverbed is shallow and deep 
scours are far from the bank, which is not the case in PIRDP. The low-spur option is less 
adaptive and flexible than revetment and does not allow for phased construction in response to 
morphological  developments:  all  the  spurs  should  be  constructed  at  once.  Consequently, 
riverbank protection option by revetment was chosen as the selected design option for the 
Project.

SUMMARY ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  In the economic analysis, the economic costs and benefits of the proposed erosion 
mitigation works, i.e., geotextile bag revetment, were evaluated in Pabna Irrigation and Rural 
Development Project (PIRDP) and Meghna-Dhonagoda Irrigation Project  (MDIP) for a project 
life of 30 years, including the construction period. The costs and benefits were expressed in 
constant 2002 prices, and valued using the world price numeraire method. All taxes and duties 
were excluded in deriving the economic values. The financial costs of traded goods were 
adjusted to their respective values using the standard conversion factor of 0.9 and a shadow 
wage rate of 0.85 for agricultural labor and 0.84 for construction labor are used. In the case of 
major tradable commodities, economic values are based on border parity pricing. These price 
data were obtained from the recently completed National Water Management Plan study with 
some adjustment in accordance with the local conditions based on the benefit monitoring and 
evaluation data collected under the Command Area Development Project (CADP).  
 
B.  Economic Costs of Project 
 
2.  The capital investment and recurrent costs required for the Project were compiled and 
then distributed over 6-years in accordance with the proposed phasing of the Project before 
being valued in economic prices. Economic conversion factors were applied to the financial cost 
estimates to derive the economic costs of the various project components. The economic capital 
costs of the Project were estimated at $43.3 million. The economic costs of the immediate 
works undertaken in May-July 2002, amounting to $2.67 million, were also included in the 
economic analysis as they are an integral part of the future erosion mitigation measures. Further 
bank stabilization works were also assumed to be required during the life of the Project to 
ensure no breaches in the embankments result from erosion. The works were estimated at 
$11.9 million for PIRDP, and $9.7 million for MDIP.

Poverty remains a serious problem, with 44.3% of the population of over 130 million living under the poverty line in 
2000. This poverty line is measured using a food poverty line on the basis of a basket of food that satisfies the

Given that over 80% of the poor live in rural areas and engage in agriculture and related nonfarm activities, 
enhancing agricultural and rural development is a key to reduce poverty in the country. For the rural poor, access to 
and control of water is of fundamental importance as it is the foundation for many livelihood activities, including 
agriculture, inland and coastal fishing, transportation, and water supply. Improving water resource management has 
been given high priority in the Poverty Partnership Agreement between the Government and the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB). 
Among the water sector challenges, riverbank erosion is one of the most critical challenges with significant poverty 
implications. Annually, this natural phenomenon displaces an estimated 100,000 people, most of whom are extremely 
poor, and deprived of assets and move to riverine fringe land, embankments, and urban slums. The Project aims to 
establish cost-effective and sustainable measures and institutions to manage the process in the context of Pabna 
Irrigation and Rural Development Project (PIRDP) and Meghna-Dhonagoda Irrigation Project (MDIP), which could be 
replicated nationwide to address this critical subsector challenge. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis  Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
Overall Status and Causes. Socioeconomic surveys undertaken during the project preparatory stage suggest that 
the incidence of poverty in PIRDP is 52.8% and in MDIP, 47.1% (including flood protection command and areas 
between the embankments and the bank lines). The causes of poverty in these areas are multidimensional. Poverty 
encompasses both income and nonincome dimensions such as education, health and nutrition, and empowerment. 
Deprivations of education, health, and nutrition are closely associated with income, but others such as voicelessness 
and insecurity are not linked in the same degree.    
In PIRDP and MDIP, the distribution of resources such as land is highly skewed. The landless account for about 62% 
of total households, and marginal households for 74%. As these areas are erosion-prone, a large number of 
households lost their homesteads, cultivable land, and other assets. Most remained in the area, adding to the number 
of poor households. The traditional social and local power structures excluded the poor from participation in  political 
and social processes. The critical issues are lack of income as well as human development such as education, health 
and nutrition, and social exclusion of the poor and women. The project area does not have any indigenous peoples. 
Economic and Social Impacts. The Project will provide a range of economic and noneconomic benefits. Economic 
benefits mainly include (i) avoided loss of lands and household assets in the riverine front, which would otherwise be 
lost to erosion; (ii) protection and enhancement of agricultural and fishery production within the flood embankments in 
particular and areas outside and along the bank line; and (iii) more jobs due to increased economic activities and 
construction works during the Project. Noneconomic and social benefits include (i) increased security of population, 
livestock, and assets; and (ii) establishment and strengthening of local institutions that will take a socially inclusive 
and participatory approach covering diverse stakeholders, including establishment of an institution to promote the 
livelihood of the erosion-displaced and most vulnerable population.  
Impacts on Employment. While the economic benefits of the Project tend to be distributed proportionately to the 
landholding size of the households, those with fewer assets will also benefit from project-related jobs. The Project is 
estimated to provide incremental agricultural jobs amounting to 460,000 labor days per annum in PIRDP and 610,000  
in MDIP, or about Tk960 per landless and Tk1,280 per marginal farm household. Labor-intensive bank protection 
work will generate about 5.1 million labor days during the investment period in PIRDP, and 3.1 million during that of 
MDIP. A total of 200,000 labor days will be required for annual operation and maintenance (O&M) activities.1  
Distribution of Project Benefits. As a part of the economic and financial analysis, the distribution of project benefits 
among stakeholders was analyzed, including an assessment to determine the extent to which the Project directly 
benefits the poor. The economic analysis showed that benefits to households were derived from land erosion, 
                                                 
1  Nonagricultural employment increased by about 1.4 million in PIRDP and 1.0 million labor days in MDIP between 
1996 and 2001, which may be accrued to flood protection and irrigation in the project area.

Appendix 13  55 
avoided flood damage, and increased agricultural and fishery development. During construction, laborers will benefit 
from jobs in labor-intensive riverbank protection works. The public sector will gain tax incomes, but will have to bear 
most of the costs of investment. Tables A13.1 to A13.2 present the results of the distribution analysis. Overall, the 
poor may attain a total of about 45% of the direct and indirect project benefits in PIRDP, and 42% of those of MDIP  
when crop and fishery production, family and hired agricultural labor, and construction labor benefits are taken into 
account. These benefits will be lost due to erosion under the without-project scenario.   
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder analysis prepared.  Yes  
The public was substantially involved in the project preparatory process. It was carried out in two rounds, the first 
through focus group discussions with smaller groups of homogeneous stakeholders in the area (i) inside and outside 
the embankment directly threatened by riverbank erosion, (ii) outside the embankment not threatened by bank 
erosion, and (iii) inside the embankment benefited from flood control, drainage and irrigation (FCDI) facilities. On the 
basis  of  focused  group  discussions,  the  second  round  was  held  in  the  form  of  local  workshops  involving 
representatives from the central and local governments, water management associations (WMAs), and civil society. 
The process generally revealed that (i) river erosion protection is strongly favored against retiring the embankments; 
(ii) nonstructural measures were identified as beneficial; (iii) people’s representation in WMAs and union parishad and 
involvement of NGOs was considered important in implementing the riverbank protection works along with the 
Bangladesh Water Development Board; and (iv) local people are willing to contribute to mitigating river erosion by 
paying irrigation service fees, taxes on fish culture, and tolls on traffic and on market places; and in kind such as 
physical labor, and supply of food, shelter, and materials (bamboo, sacks, etc.). 
Participation Strategy/ Poverty and Social Development Strategy.  Yes 
(i)  Targeted Interventions to the Erosion-displaced Poor. Over 10,000 people in PIRDP and MDIP who were 
displaced by river erosion now live on the riverine fringe, particularly on the flood embankments, as illegal squatters. 
They are mostly landless and poor, with over 70% living below the poverty line, have very limited physical assets, and 
earn daily wages, or are self-employed. With the engagement of experienced NGOs, the Project, under its social 
development subcomponent, will organize this most vulnerable population, specifically targeting female-headed and 
other low-income groups to stimulate their self-help efforts.2  
(ii)  Enhancing Socially Inclusive Participatory Water Management. In line with the 1999 National Water Policy, 
which promotes participatory and comprehensive management of water, the Project will establish Joint Management 
Committees (JMCs) to play key roles in decision making on water resources management, including riverbank 
erosion management, irrigation and drainage, and agricultural and fishery development. The Project’s institutional 
strengthening component will focus on developing a firm institutional basis to affiliate stakeholder institutions such as 
WMAs.  Their  membership  status  will  be  substantially  strengthened  through  involvement  of  consultants, 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and  community-based  organizers  (CBOs).  JMC  will  also  include 
representatives of the diverse stakeholders, including the most vulnerable groups. JMCs and subproject management 
offices (SMOs) will also form an emergency riverbank protection group (ERPG) to provide labor for emergency works 
during the flood season. ERPG representatives will also participate in construction quality assurance, e.g., throughout 
the JMC subcommittee for joint construction inspection. 
(iii) Gender Strategy and Actions. The Project will try to increase the participation and role of women in WMAs, 
and JMCs. With the help of consultants, NGOs, and CBOs, the Project’s nonstructural mitigation and institutional-
strengthening components will (i) set up a special network for women members of these stakeholder institutions, (ii) 
establish numerical targets for enrollment of female members and engagement of female laborers for earthwork and 
other project-related activities, and (iii) provide special training for women-only groups through WMAs. Gender-
specific monitoring indicators will be identified and gender-relevant information included and documented in the 
Project’s management information system to be developed with the consultants.  
(iv) Engagement of the Poor as Construction Labor. To place sand-filled geotextile bags in the river channel, the 
Project will require an estimated 1.4 million labor days per annum during the implementation or over 50% of the total 
agricultural jobs in the project area. To ensure the highest benefit to the poor, the local population, in particular poor 
and vulnerable, will be engaged as construction labor for the works, for which wage rates will be fixed transparently.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK AND RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
 
A.  Resettlement Framework for the Riverbank Protection Works 
 
1.  Scope  and  Impact.  The  resettlement  framework  includes  the  framework  for  the 
proposed 7.0 km and 4.4 km of protection work for the flood embankments along the Jamuna 
and Meghna rivers in Pabna Irrigation and Rural Development Project (PIRDP) and Meghna-
Dhonagoda Irrigation Project (MDIP) respectively, to protect the project area from progressive 
river erosion. The revetment works will be implemented over 6 years. The total amount of land 
acquired for revetment is estimated at 35 hectares (ha) in PIRDP and 22 ha in MDIP, which will 
be eroded without project intervention. Their exact locations and impacts have to be reviewed 
and finalized during the final design stage, when the alignments for the protection works will be 
decided based on morphological development. Project implementation is expected to start in the 
first quarter of 2003.  
 
2.  Resettlement Policy. Resettlement will be implemented in accordance with the policy 
on involuntary resettlement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and following the passage of 
the (i) Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property (ARIP) Ordinance 1982; and (ii) East 
Bengal State Acquisition and Tenancy Act (1951, revised 1994).    
 
3.  Resettlement Principles, Entitlements, and Procedures. The resettlement framework 
applies to all involuntary resettlement effects, including displacement of nontitled people, arising 
from land acquisition or conversion, or any other effects that result from project works on the 
floodplain, bank line, and any other land affected by the Project, including that required for 
embankment work and char lands lost due to the project works. Those affected will be helped to 
maintain at least their standard of living at preproject level. All losses, including of land, crops, 
trees, structures, business, employment, and workdays and wages, will be fully compensated, 
including those incurred by nontitled people. The owners of land acquired for protection work, 
including bank line and eroded land within the 50-meter right-of-way acquisition, will be fully 
compensated.  Affected  households  will  receive  (i)  an  additional  cash  grant  to  match 
replacement value to supplement the grant provided by the deputy commissioner, and (ii) other 
resettlement assistance such as shifting allowances and compensation for loss of workdays 
and/or income due to dislocation. Female-headed and other vulnerable households will be 
eligible for further cash assistance for relocation and house reconstruction. People involuntarily 
displaced, including nontitled people, will receive priority assistance under the Project’s social 
development subcomponent. 
 
4.  Institutional  Responsibilities  and  Procedures.  The  project  management  office 
(PMO), under the responsibility of the chief resettlement and environmental management officer 
at  the  rank  of  executive  engineer,  has  overall  planning,  financing,  and  supervisory 
responsibilities for resettlement plan preparation and implementation to be carried out by the 
subproject management offices (SMOs) with designated resettlement and social development 
officer. PMO will engage experienced NGO and consultants to assist the process. Each year, 
upon identification of the bank lines for protection after the monsoon season, the following 
procedures are to be carried out: (i) PMO will undertake impact assessment surveys based on 
technical designs; and (ii) depending on the significance of the impacts, PMO will prepare full or 
short  resettlement  plans  for  the  protected  section,  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  policy  on 
involuntary resettlement and other social safeguard guidelines. The full or short resettlement 
plans will be submitted to ADB for approval, and people affected should be fully compensated 
before award of the relevant civil works contracts. BWDB will ensure that resettlement budgets

Appendix 21  59 
are delivered on time to the deputy commissioner’s office and the implementing nongovernment 
organization (NGO) for timely resettlement plan implementation.  
 
5.  Disclosure, Consultation and Grievances. Each resettlement plan will be prepared 
and  implemented  in  close  consultation  with  the  stakeholders  and  will  involve  focus  group 
discussions  and  meetings,  particularly  with  the  project  affected  persons.  Copies  of  draft 
resettlement plan will be distributed among NGOs and community groups prior to finalizing the 
engineering  design.  A  grievances  redress  committee  (GRC)  will  be  established  with 
representatives from PMO, affected persons, women and vulnerable groups, local government, 
and NGOs. The chief resettlement officer will chair the GRC. Other than disputes relating to 
ownership rights under the court of law, GRC will review grievances involving all resettlement 
benefits,  relocation,  and  other  assistance.  Any  grievances  submitted  to  the  GRC  will  be 
resolved within 2–3 weeks. 
 
6.  Monitoring  and  Evaluation.  Bangladesh  Water  Development  Board  (BWDB)  will 
establish a monthly monitoring system involving PMO, SMOs and implementing NGO staff, and 
prepare  progress  reports  on  all  aspects  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  and  social 
development efforts and outcomes. External monitoring will be assigned to an independent local 
expert and agency and report to BWDB and ADB quarterly. BWDB will also report to ADB on 
land acquisition and resettlement and social development in the quarterly progress report. 
 
7.  Resettlement  Cost.  The  cost  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  is  estimated  at 
Tk109.7 million ($1.91 million) excluding NGO services. The Government will provide the entire 
fund for land acquisition and resettlement, and will guarantee meeting unforeseen obligations in 
excess of the budget estimate to meet the resettlement objectives.    
 
B.  Short Resettlement Plan for the Secondary Embankments In PIRDP 
 
8.  Scope and Impacts. The short resettlement plan is associated with the construction of a 
1.2-kilometer  secondary  defense  line  of  embankments  to  protect  some  critical  sections  of 
embankments in PIRDP. The plan will be implemented in 2003. The construction of the second 
defense line will require acquisition of an estimated 10 hectares. The proposed alignment 
largely consists of low-lying agricultural land. As a result, the project impact is limited to three 
households only (18 affected persons). An estimated 30 households will lose limited agricultural 
lands from strip acquisition.  
 
9.  Resettlement Policy. Resettlement will be in accordance with the ARIP Ordinance and 
in accordance with ADB’s policy on involuntary resettlement. 
 
10.  Stakeholder Consultation and Entitlements. During the project preparatory stage, a 
consultation  was  held  covering  the  secondary  defense  line  area.  The  feedback  and 
observations made at the stakeholders’ meetings have been used in preparing the entitlement 
matrix  and  project  benefits  for  affected  people.  No  nontitled  people  were  affected.  The 
entitlement matrix recognizes seven types of losses to cover all potential losses, including loss 
of access by tenants (Table A14).
